item.title: fmm_simp
item.description: MLE for Normal densities Assumptions Our sample is made up of the first $n$ terms of an IID sequence ${X_{n}}$ of normal random variables having mean $\mu_{0}$ and variance $\sigma_{0}^{2}$. The probability density function of a generic term of the sequence is $$f_{X}\left(x_{j}\right)=\left(2\pi\sigma_{0}^{2}\right)^{-1/2}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}\frac{\left(x_{j}-\mu_{0}\right)^{2}}{\sigma_{0}^{2}}\right)$$ The mean $\mu_{0}$ and the variance $\sigma_{0}^{2}$ are the two parameters that need to be estimated. The log-likelihood function log-likelihood function: $$\begin{aligned} L(\mu,\sigma^{2};x_{1},\ldots x_{n}) & =\prod_{i=1}^{n}(2\pi\sigma^{2})^{-1/2}\exp\bigg(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}(x_{i}-\mu)^{2}\bigg)\\ & =(2\pi\sigma^{2})^{-n/2}\exp\bigg(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x-\mu)^{2}\bigg)\\ \end{aligned}$$ .

item.title: FMM_original
item.description: MLE for Normal densities Unconditional version adapted from https://www.statlect.com/fundamentals-of-statistics/normal-distribution-maximum-likelihood Assumptions Our sample is made up of the first $n$ terms of an IID sequence ${X_{n}}$ of normal random variables having mean $\mu_{0}$ and variance $\sigma_{0}^{2}$. The probability density function of a generic term of the sequence is $$f_{X}\left(x_{j}\right)=\left(2\pi\sigma_{0}^{2}\right)^{-1/2}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{2}\frac{\left(x_{j}-\mu_{0}\right)^{2}}{\sigma_{0}^{2}}\right)$$ The mean $\mu_{0}$ and the variance $\sigma_{0}^{2}$ are the two parameters that need to be estimated. The log-likelihood function $$\begin{aligned} L(\mu,\sigma^{2};x_{1},\ldots x_{n}) & =\prod_{i=1}^{n}(2\pi\sigma^{2})^{-1/2}\exp\bigg(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}(x_{i}-\mu)^{2}\bigg)\\ & =(2\pi\sigma^{2})^{-n/2}\exp\bigg(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x-\mu)^{2}\bigg)\\ \Rightarrow l(\mu,\sigma^{2};x_{1},\ldots x_{n}) & =\ln L(\mu,\sigma^{2};x_{1},\ldots x_{n})\\ & =\ln\Bigg[(2\pi\sigma^{2})^{-n/2}\exp\bigg(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x-\mu)^{2}\bigg)\Bigg]\\ & =-\frac{n}{2}\ln(2\pi\sigma^{2})-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}-\mu)^{2}\\ & =-\frac{n}{2}\ln(2\pi)-\dfrac{n}{2}\ln\sigma^{2}-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\sum_{i=1}^{n}(x_{i}-\mu)^{2} \end{aligned}$$ ML estimator $$\max_{\mu,\sigma^{2}}l(\mu,\sigma^{2};x_{1},\ldots x_{n})$$
